{
  "response": "Bash scripting is the practice of writing a series of commands in a plain‑text file (usually with a `.sh` extension) so that the Bash (Bourne Again Shell) interpreter can execute them automatically. It lets users and system administrators automate repetitive tasks—such as updating packages, backing up data, or processing files—by converting multiple command‑line steps into a single executable script [[1]](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/linux-unix/bash-scripting-introduction-to-bash-and-bash-scripting/)[[2]](https://www.hostinger.com/tutorials/bash-scripting-tutorial). Because Bash is the default login shell on most Linux distributions and is also available on Windows and macOS, scripts written for Bash are highly portable across Unix‑like environments [[2]](https://www.hostinger.com/tutorials/bash-scripting-tutorial)[[3]](https://itsfoss.com/bash-scripting-tutorial/).

## Sources

[1] Bash Scripting - Introduction to Bash and Bash Scripting - GeeksforGeeks - https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/linux-unix/bash-scripting-introduction-to-bash-and-bash-scripting/
[2] Bash scripting tutorial for beginners - https://www.hostinger.com/tutorials/bash-scripting-tutorial
[3] Bash Scripting Tutorial for Beginners - https://itsfoss.com/bash-scripting-tutorial/

Sources used:

{
  "response": "The **python** tag on Stack Overflow is used for any question that involves the Python programming language, which is a dynamically‑typed, multi‑purpose language known for its clean syntax and rapid development speed.  The tag description notes that Python is interpreted, object‑oriented, and supports several paradigms (imperative, functional, etc.), and it points users to include version‑specific tags (e.g., python‑3.x) when relevant [[16]](https://stackoverflow.com/tags/python/info).  Because Python is one of the most discussed topics on the site—ranking among the top eight tags alongside JavaScript, Java, C#, PHP, Android, and HTML—it attracts a large volume of questions and answers, reflecting its broad adoption among developers [[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_Overflow).  Recent developer‑survey data also show Python as one of the most used and most loved languages, underscoring why the tag remains highly active on Stack Overflow [[9]](https://electroiq.com/stats/stack-overflow-statistics/).

## Sources

[1] Stack Overflow - Wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_Overflow
[9] Stack Overflow Statistics And Facts (2025) - https://electroiq.com/stats/stack-overflow-statistics/
[16] None - https://stackoverflow.com/tags/python/info

{
  "response": "The modulo operator in Python is written as **%** and returns the remainder after dividing the left‑hand operand (the dividend) by the right‑hand operand (the divisor). It works with integers, floating‑point numbers, and even with negative values, but the sign of the result always follows the sign of the divisor b (e.g., ‑5 % 3 yields 1, while 5 % ‑3 yields ‑1) [[1]](https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/python/modulo)[[3]](https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/articles/python-modulo-operator/). The divisor cannot be zero; attempting a % 0 raises a ZeroDivisionError [[2]](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/python/what-is-a-modulo-operator-in-python/)[[8]](https://codefather.tech/blog/python-modulo/). For cases where you need both the quotient and the remainder in one call, Python provides the built‑in divmod(a, b) function, which returns a tuple (quotient, remainder) and follows the same floor‑division rules for negative numbers [[15]](https://docs.vultr.com/python/built-in/divmod)[[18]](https://coderivers.org/blog/python-divmod/).

## Sources

[1] Python | Modulo | Codecademy - https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/python/modulo
[2] Modulo operator (%) in Python - GeeksforGeeks - https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/python/what-is-a-modulo-operator-in-python/
[3] Python Modulo Operator - https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/articles/python-modulo-operator/
[8] How can I calculate the remainder of a division in Python? - https://codefather.tech/blog/python-modulo/
[15] Python divmod() - Quotient and Remainder | Vultr Docs - https://docs.vultr.com/python/built-in/divmod
[18] Python `divmod` Function: A Comprehensive Guide - CodeRivers - https://coderivers.org/blog/python-divmod/

{
  "response": "`client.chat.completions.create` is the primary method in the OpenAI Python SDK for invoking the **Chat Completions** endpoint. It sends a request that includes the model identifier (e.g., `"gpt‑4"` or `"gpt‑3.5‑turbo"`), a list of message objects that represent the conversation history (each with a `role` of `system`, `user`, or `assistant` and a `content` string), and optional parameters such as `temperature`, `max_tokens`, `top_p`, etc. The call returns a response object whose `choices` array contains the generated messages, accessible via `response.choices[0].message.content`[[1]](https://medium.com/@Doug-Creates/nightmares-and-client-chat-completions-create-29ad0acbe16a)[[2]](https://medium.com/@laoluoyefolu/the-openai-api-chat-completions-22349b3df941)[[5]](https://tiptap.dev/docs/content-ai/capabilities/agent/custom-llms/get-started/openai-chat-completions).  

Typical usage looks like:

```python
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()                     # initialize the SDK
response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",
    messages=[
        {"role": "system", "content": "You are a helpful assistant."},
        {"role": "user",   "content": "Write a one‑sentence bedtime story about a unicorn."}
    ],
    temperature=0.7,
    max_tokens=150
)
print(response.choices[0].message.content)
```

The method provides flexibility for developers who need full control over chat behavior, while newer `.parse()` helpers add structured‑output safety on top of the same endpoint[[6]](https://medium.com/@swatiagrawal_26/openai-sdks-create-vs-parse-with-chat-response-and-beta-apis-1b06a674268d).

## Sources

[1] Using client.chat.completions.create() | by Doug Creates | Medium - https://medium.com/@Doug-Creates/nightmares-and-client-chat-completions-create-29ad0acbe16a
[2] The OpenAI API: Chat Completions - https://medium.com/@laoluoyefolu/the-openai-api-chat-completions-22349b3df941
[5] Get started with the OpenAI Chat Completions API | Tiptap Content AI - https://tiptap.dev/docs/content-ai/capabilities/agent/custom-llms/get-started/openai-chat-completions
[6] OpenAI SDK’s “.create()” vs “.parse()” with Chat, Response, and Beta APIs | by Swati Agrawal | Medium - https://medium.com/@swatiagrawal_26/openai-sdks-create-vs-parse-with-chat-response-and-beta-apis-1b06a674268d

{
  "response": "Use the name of an OpenAI chat‑completion model as the `model` argument, e.g.:

```python
client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",      # or any other chat‑completion model name
    messages=[…],
    …
)
```

The OpenAI /v1/chat/completions endpoint supports a variety of model identifiers such as `gpt-4o`, `gpt-4o-mini`, `o1-preview`, `o1-mini`, `o3-mini`, etc. These names are passed as a string to the `model` parameter [[9]](https://community.openai.com/t/api-models-for-a-specific-feature/1128474)[[5]](https://arxiv.org/abs/2505.07522).

## Sources

[5] Byam: Fixing Breaking Dependency Updates with Large Language Models - https://arxiv.org/abs/2505.07522
[9] Api models for a specific feature - API - OpenAI Developer Community - https://community.openai.com/t/api-models-for-a-specific-feature/1128474

{
  "response": "Recent weather has been marked by a series of extreme events worldwide. In January 2025 an unusually cold snap pushed temperatures 20–35 °F (11–19 °C) below average across much of the United States, Canada and Mexico, while the summer brought a historic tornado outbreak in the Northern United States that included the first EF5 tornado recorded since 2013 [[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_of_2025). March 2025 saw multiple wildfires in Texas and Oklahoma driven by hurricane‑force gusts and very low humidity, and similar fire activity spread across northern Minnesota under “unprecedented” heat conditions [[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_of_2025).  

These events occur against a backdrop of ongoing global warming. The World Meteorological Organization projects that the annual global mean near‑surface temperature for 2025‑2029 will be 1.2 °C–1.9 °C higher than the 1850‑1900 baseline, with an 80 % chance that at least one of those years will surpass the warmest year on record [[2]](https://wmo.int/news/media-centre/global-climate-predictions-show-temperatures-expected-remain-or-near-record-levels-coming-5-years). 2024 already set a record as the first calendar year likely exceeding 1.5 °C above pre‑industrial levels, a warming that has intensified heatwaves, heavy rainfall, droughts and sea‑level rise [[2]](https://wmo.int/news/media-centre/global-climate-predictions-show-temperatures-expected-remain-or-near-record-levels-coming-5-years).  The previous year also produced the highest number of new displacements from extreme weather in 16 years, driven largely by hotter temperatures that increase the frequency and severity of floods, cyclones and droughts [[4]](https://earth.org/extreme-weather-events-in-2024-led-to-highest-number-of-new-displacements-since-2008/).  NASA data further highlight a dramatic rise in the intensity of droughts and floods over the past five years, underscoring how climate change is amplifying the magnitude of such events [[5]](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/jun/17/nasa-data-reveals-dramatic-rise-in-intensity-of-weather-events).  In summary, the combination of record‑breaking heat, unprecedented cold snaps, severe storms and expanding wildfires reflects a climate system increasingly prone to extreme weather as global temperatures continue to climb [[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change).

## Sources

[2] World Weather Repository ( Daily Updating ) | Kaggle - https://wmo.int/news/media-centre/global-climate-predictions-show-temperatures-expected-remain-or-near-record-levels-coming-5-years
[3] Climate change: global temperature | NOAA Climate.gov - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_of_2025
[4] World still on track for catastrophic 2.6C temperature rise, report finds | Environment | The Guardian - https://earth.org/extreme-weather-events-in-2024-led-to-highest-number-of-new-displacements-since-2008/
[5] Global climate predictions show temperatures expected to remain at or near record levels in coming 5 years - https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/jun/17/nasa-data-reveals-dramatic-rise-in-intensity-of-weather-events
